page.title: 19HISTORY OF GIMORTON
page.content: The village is in the Domesday Book and is called "Mortons". The entry reads that in Gilmorton wapentake Robert of Vessey holds Gilmorton from the King and Godfrey from him. The value of the land was 10 shillings before 1066 and 40 shillings by the time of the Domesday Survey in 1085.Sometime after the Survey Mortons acquired the prefix of "Goldinge" or Gildinge". It is thought that this addition to the name was due to an abundance of a weed called "golding" or "gilding", growing in the area, a weed natural to the soil and ruinous to the corn. It had a yellow flower, hence the name "golding". The lordship was enclosed in 1777 and Sir Wolstan Dixie was Lord of the manor, but owned only a small proportion of the land. The principal landowners were the Chandler family.
